One 256-bit memory module can store one bit in the addresses from 0 to 255. If you only used one 256-bit memory, you would be able to store 256 one bit values (so either 1 or 0). Maybe I don't understand your question properly, but how would you use a 256-bit memory to store a byte, when each address can store only 1 bit at a time? Since one address only stores one bit, you can combine 8 256-bit memory modules to store 256 8-bit values (1*8 = 8).

Super interesting question so first off thanks for posing the challenge! I'm no expert by any means but my guess is that it requires less 'switching' the way they have it set up. In your setup, storing 1 8-bit number would require changing addresses 8 times, albeit writing in one 256 bit box. With their setup you'd only need to change addresses once each new 8-bit number you're storing.  Their way it's also easier to remember that each address stores 1 number. In your setup you'd need to remember where the 8 bit number starts and where it ends (which would be easy enough as they'd be multiples of 8, but it's still more complicated than just saying ok address XY, box 3 is the 3rd digit of the number stored at XY).  TL;DR the condensed image at 9:18 wouldn't look as neat as you wouldn't be able to say 1 address = 1 number

Random Access means that you can access any part of it at any given time. It can give you back the value of any random address you ask for. There was also serial memory in the older days, where if you wanted to read a byte from some position, you had to read every byte up to that position. For example, if you wanted to read from address 255, with RAM you can just ask for that address and it will give you the value, but serial memory would require you to read through addresses 0-254 first.

Those are SR-Latch and D-Latch. D-latch is a gated SR Latch. (Unoptimized for illustration purposes.) Most have edge detection in synchronous circuits which can be called flip flops, while asynchronous use latches. Asynchronous circuits are screaming fast, yet power hungry. Most computer circuits are synchronous. ASICs tend to be the ones that are asynchronous but can be either or. A lot of SRAM is build around gate based memory which is costly in terms of area due to gates not wires. These gates need metal layers (wires) to interconnect, so what they do is use lower levels to increase density. Then connect them into cells which reduces wires that would waste area  or density. So they use mid to upper layers for the wires of the cells. Better known as locality. SRAM is fast but expensive and power hungry. Slower DRAM uses more capacitor like mediums sometimes with a single transistor for driving versus whole gates which use multiple transistors. This allows an increase in density but lowers performance and possibly power. However power tends to increase with bit density, but increasing density may also lower power or normalize it out. One thing about wires is they tend to form low pass filters, which creates delays or limits performance. Architecture generally handles this which also tends to decide how the matrix is arranged. These factors also predict the tradeoff of wires to gates in said matrix.

I love this series: it's like going back to the basics in school in the 70's!  One correction though: the early (_really_ early) single chiop CPU's (i.e., "Microcomputers") were 4 bits wide, not 8!  The Intel 8008 was the first CPU on a chip for the general consumer market, and it was 4 bits wide. It's later sister chip was the 8080, which was 8 bits wide, and was the chip on which general purpose microcomputing was born on the IBM "home computers".  Of course there were dozens of microcomputers before the IBM debacle permanently screwed up computing forever: the more famous chips were the 6800 (the first one I used to build a home computer), the 6502, the 6809 (kind of an upgrade to the 6800, like the 8080 was an upgrade to the 8008), and the T.I. 99's brain, the TMS9900. Good job on this series though!

Very informative and easy to understand. But when you're talking about selecting rows and columns, didn't you mean "decoder" as opposed to "multiplexer"? A multiplexer on the other hand selects which of the inputs (2 ^ select bits)  it passes to the output.

Leban Bo All computers are send "digital signals." Digital signals are square waves, as they can be a 1, or a 0, and not in between, so they have a square shape. Electrical engineers and physicists use the term "square wave," and computer engineers use the term digital signal. Anything more detailed than this is a topic for a data communications course.  The wave pattern is logically generated by the Instruction Set Architecture, which will be talked about in a later video, I imagine.

I'm not an electrical or a computer engineer, but it would have to be some part that change it's action based on voltage. While in theory we have 1's and 0's with perfect square waves, in reality we have ranges to determine the values based on voltage. A 1 is declared as a certain range, a 0 as another, and a very low voltage is used to be "off." So I would look up things that "read" voltage and go from there. Sorry I can't be more helpful!

There is a circuit in the DRAM chip which is called "sense amplifier" which measures the voltage on the capacitor. It produces an output that indicates if the sensed charge above the threshold value. This eventually becomes the logic output signal from the memory chip. Although this is very simple in principle, it is done in quite clever and complicated ways in reality. You will need solid understanding of physics and electronics to appreciate what the problems are how they are being solved.

There is a good book available for free on-line "Dram circuit design: a tutorial." It covers everything in detail, but it is written for professionals.  The details require lots of explaining. It certainly can be understood, if you spend time and effort. I can give you another reference, but you may have to start with learning the necessary physics and electronics before it will make any sense to you.  Go to a channel: "nptelhrd" (The channel provides technical lectures from seven Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) and Indian Institute of Science (IISc) Bangalore.)  Go to playlist: "Electrical - Digital Integrated Circuits"  Watch the lecture: "Lecture 35 DRAM-CMOS and BiCMOS".  If it does not make sense, start from the first lecture in the playlist. If it still makes no sense, try playlist "Electronics - Basic Electrical Circuits" I hope this helps.

the keyword: speed. if you load the data in parallel it's a lot faster. with 8 blocks of 256b you can send every block 1b at the same time, if you want to put everything in the first block, you have to load bit1, bit2, bit3 etc after eachother, which makes it 8 times slower. Imagine the data bus is a road, the block a parking garage and the bits are cars, if you have 8 parking places each with their own entrance, all cars can drive in at the same time. if you have only one garage, you have to wait until the cars in front of you have gone in before you can go in. as you can see, spreading the data between the blocks makes it a lot faster

Came here because I was initially confused too.   The number 256 was chosen because we want to create 256 'slots' to store values.   "One 256-bit memory unit" means we have 256 'slots' for storing 1-bit values.  Slot 1: 0 Slot 2: 1 ... Slot 256: 0  But in this lesson we are interested in 8-bit values. In order to store 8-bit values, we'll have "one 256-bit memory unit" for each of these 8 bits.  Memory unit for Bit #1 Slot 1: 0 Slot 2: 1 ... Slot 256: 0  Memory unit for Bit #2 Slot 1: 1 Slot 2: 0 ... Slot 256: 1  ...  Memory unit for Bit #8 Slot 1: 1 Slot 2: 1 ... Slot 256: 0  To retrieve an 8-bit value stored at say Slot 2, we can read the 1-bit stored at Slot 2 for each of the eight memory units.
It's basically the same thing. "Decoder" is just a more general term.

I have to disagree with this. Hakan Sonmez is right; A decoder takes a BCD (binary coded decimal) and outputs the decimal equivalent, whereas an encoder does the opposite. A multiplexer on the other hand selects from a list of inputs and outputs only one of those inputs.

A decoder could be ANY circuit that takes `m` inputs and decodes it into `n` outputs according to some predefined pattern. It doesn't have to be BCD on the input nor decimal on the output. Also, what's "decimal output"? Logic circuits don't work in decimal. If anything, a BCD to "decimal" decoder simply selects one of the 10 outputs according to the binary number on the input, so it's pretty much the same thing as a multiplexer with a constant signal 1. A proper multiplexer would take one more input to know what kind of signal to put on one of those 10 outputs.

What she's actually referring to is a decoder not a multiplexor (they're very similar though). Here's a diagram of a 3-bit decoder:  http://cpuville.com/images/decoder_3.jpg

And ROM (read-only memory). Basically, RAM is the memory the computer is currently working with and is erased as soon as the power is cut off. ROM is memory that is stored on a media, ie punchcard, cassete, disc, etc.

Not exactly.  ROM cannot be written to frequently, so cassettes, discs, and punchcards would not be considered ROM.  Those are physical media or physical storage which persist data even when there's no power.  ROM is for stuff that can't be changed as fast such as a PC's bios or a devices firmware.  ROM can't be written to as much or as fast or as easily as RAM.

I think you misunderstood, you don't need 8 to store a byte, you need 8 to store *256 bytes.* It accesses a bit at the same location in each of the eight blocks to form a byte - for example, if I want to access byte 0x13, I access bit 0x13 from block 1, bit 0x13 from block 2, bit 0x13 from block 3, and so on.
